session_1747365896313_2jbxx2m: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
column3: I don't support the policy at all because we have a small town and there's a lot of people already. We are in a college town, usually when students come in, we have like 30 or 40% more traffic at least or more.

session_1747365896313_2jbxx2m: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
column3: The positive probably behind more benefits or more income for the restaurants and retails. Negative would be traffic, parking, housing. That's a lot of problems. Because if we only increase the housing without parking, without public transportation, without sewage system, all those things taken into consideration, then it would create a problem for all of us.

session_1747365896313_2jbxx2m: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
column3: The housing, rental, whatever, is so high now, I don't think a lot of people can afford it. So even like 10%, 30%, it's still not gonna cut it. We have some tall buildings only built in the last five, 10 years. And we still empty spaces there. And downtown, we still have empty retail spaces for rent. So taller building doesn't mean it's affordable. When you mean affordable, a lot of people cannot afford it, actually.

session_1747365896313_2jbxx2m: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
column3: dense area means more traffic, more, you know, problems, social problems, like noise, you know, more, don't know, maybe crime, could it be? It's, you know, inescapable. So we have a lot of problems already, and you just add more if we have more dense neighborhood.

session_1747365896313_2jbxx2m: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
column3: Our public transportation is there, but it's not perfect, and mostly just for students. And if you put more dense area building and then no parking, no public transportation, also no other help, then it definitely would create a lot of traffic and congestion. Nowadays, we have more traffic congestion because a lot of renovation or reconstruction on the road.

session_1747365896313_2jbxx2m: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
column3: The local government should do it slowly, just test it out, maybe one or two, see how it goes. Because what we have seen is it's not affordable for a lot of people because still empty spaces in houses, buildings that built last 10 years. If you suddenly put in like 7, 8, 10 tall buildings, we don't really know what the impact is. You only benefit the builders and the local didn't really get a lot because you only have like 10, 15 affordable in each 10 buildings, then it's not a lot. And that's called affordable, it means maybe 10, 20% less, but still very, very expensive nowadays.

session_1747365896313_2jbxx2m: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
column3: Well, definitely going to be more noise, probably going to be more garbage and sewage problem. Those utility monthly costs are going to go up and the rest of us going to help pay for it.

session_1747365896313_2jbxx2m: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
column3: More people means more profits for retails, shops. You know, it's good for them, but it's not good for the rest of the city because all the locals are gonna get a lot of noise and we pay more for our utility bills. We probably have to pay more, you know, to maintain the road or canals. You know, the impact we don't know yet and we may have to pay to fix it later on.

session_1747365896313_2jbxx2m: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
column3: And I don't know why we have to put all the dense building into the existing residential area. I think the government or the local government or state government should think if there is an open space, we can put those tall buildings there and then just test it out. Maybe build a public transportation there from the area into downtown and see how it goes instead of just put everything, changing everything in the existing city fabric.

session_1747365896313_2jbxx2m: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
column3: I don't think we have much to say about it, except for like, you know, we can voice, but usually we downplay that as a citizen, because all the builders, you know, they somehow they convince, you know, the people in the city, county, and it's a good idea. But those people, I think it's pretty short sighted, and they're only thinking about like, for, you know, 30%, you know, 15%, so-called affordable housing, and it's not a lot. So pretty much it's, you know, like, this is a huge opportunity for builders to benefit from it. And the rest of us, we have to help pay for it, actually. And for that, you know, 15%.

column3: I think definitely would help for the support, you know, because, you know, we're human, we thought about that, you know, we really want to help, but not to the extent that you impact us negatively in our own life. We want to help. So if we do it slowly, then we, at least, you know, any big, any impact, at least, you know, as a minimize it to the rest of us, and we can think something else. That's an example already. You know, like we already have like 70, those, you know, high density buildings, building or being built. And now suddenly another mayor or something said, oh, we want to petition for another, you know, thing on the ballot in November, because we want to do it another way. And we want to get, you know, some tax, you know, income, and then we want to, you know, try this, you know, other way to do it. So see, people seeing it is not going to cut it.
